required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison Study of Wound Closure at Time of Cesarean Delivery: Dermabond Glue Versus Surgical Staples
clinical_study.official_title: A Comparative Study of Closure Techniques After Cesarean Section: Staples vs. Dermabond

brief_summary.textblock: Women who have a cesarean delivery have a surgical incision on their abdomen (belly). The usual way to close this opening is with metal surgical staples. In many other types of surgery, surgical incisions are closed with a super-glue called Dermabond. The researchers at the University of Massachusetts believe Dermabond may be a safe alternative to using staples at the time of a cesarean delivery, but this has not been studied. Women who choose to participate will be randomly assigned to have the cesarean delivery skin incision closed with staples or Dermabond. The researchers will survey the patients to see how they felt about the experience and the appearance of their scar. The researchers will survey physicians performing the surgery to see how easy Dermabond was to use. The researchers will ask physicians to evaluate the appearance of the incision after a 6-week recovery period and will analyze complications (such as bruising, infection, or separation of the wound) in the two groups.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Poor enrollment, much data was missing as patients were lost to follow up

primary_outcome.time_frame: within six weeks of study intervention
primary_outcome.description: Wound seroma or hematoma, wound separation, wound requiring packing, cellulitis, required extra medical clinic visits to evaluate wound

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Satisfaction of Cosmesis of Surgical Wound
secondary_outcome.description: survey questionnaire using a visual analog scale to inquire about incision appearance, satisfaction with method of closure and comparison to previous closure type (if applicable)

arm_group.description: Women receiving Dermabond for skin closure
Women receiving standard surgical skin staples

intervention.description: Standard method to close abdominal surgical wounds
Alternative method (superglue) to close abdominal surgical wounds

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women undergoing scheduled and non-scheduled cesarean deliveries
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prisoners
- Insulin-requiring diabetics
- Vertical skin incision
- Allergy to Dermabond

participant_flow.recruitment_details: September 4, 2007-July 9, 2010 Recruitment occured in the medical clinics and Labor and Delivery unit of an academic medical center
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The study design dictates that patients be enrolled upon admission to Labor and Delivery. Subsequently, patients who did not deliver by cesarean delivery would be excluded

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
